author: Morgan Housel
summary: People are poor forecasters of their future selves. The 'End of History Illusion' means we underestimate how much we'll change. Avoid extreme financial planning because what seems right today may not fit who you become.
key_takeaways: People are poor forecasters of their future selves - the 'End of History Illusion'.
Avoid extreme ends of financial planning to reduce future regret.
Accept the reality of changing your mind - have no sunk costs.

questions.question: What is the 'End of History Illusion'?

options.text: Believing historical events will never repeat
Being aware of past changes but underestimating how much you'll change in the future
Thinking the economy has stopped evolving

questions.explanation: The End of History Illusion is the tendency for people to be keenly aware of how much they've changed in the past, but to underestimate how much their personalities, desires, and goals will change in the future.

questions.question: Why should you avoid extreme financial plans like living on very little or working endless hours for maximum income?

options.text: Because the tax implications are worse at extremes
Because the benefits of extremes wear off while the downsides become enduring regrets
Because financial advisors won't work with extreme clients
Because banks prefer moderate account holders

questions.explanation: People adapt to most circumstances, so the benefits of an extreme plan wear off. But the downsides - not affording retirement or looking back at a life chasing dollars - become enduring regrets.

questions.question: What did Daniel Kahneman mean when he said 'I have no sunk costs'?

options.text: He never spent money on projects
He could abandon past work and start fresh without feeling anchored to previous efforts
He only worked on free projects

questions.explanation: Sunk costs make our future selves prisoners to our past, different selves. Embracing that financial goals made when you were a different person should be abandoned without mercy helps minimize future regret.
